questions.subtask: D-12.02 Constructs dimensional lumber wall framing
questions.question: When framing a header using dimensional lumber, what is the typical construction method?

options.B: Two or more boards on edge with spacer

explanations.A: Flat orientation provides inadequate strength
explanations.B: Headers typically consist of two or more boards installed on edge (vertical orientation) with spacer material between to match wall thickness, providing maximum strength
explanations.C: Flat stacking is inefficient and provides less strength than on-edge installation
explanations.D: Single boards are typically insufficient for header loads

questions.question: What safety consideration is unique to engineered panel installation?

options.B: Panels are lighter than stick framing, reducing risk
options.C: Large panels can act as sails in wind; weather considerations critical
options.D: Safety requirements are identical to stick framing

explanations.A: Large panels present specific safety challenges
explanations.B: Panels are often heavier and larger, not lighter
explanations.C: Large wall panels catch wind easily and can become unstable or dangerous during lifting and before being secured; wind conditions must be monitored carefully
explanations.D: Panel installation has additional safety considerations beyond stick framing

questions.subtask: D-12.02 Constructs dimensional lumber wall framing
questions.question: What is the maximum height differential allowed between adjoining wall sections before installation?

explanations.A: Height variations must be controlled for proper floor/ceiling connections
explanations.B: Wall height variations should not exceed approximately 6 mm to ensure proper bearing and alignment for floor or roof systems above
explanations.C: This variation would create problems with upper-level framing
explanations.D: This much variation is unacceptable for quality construction

questions.subtask: D-12.02 Constructs dimensional lumber wall framing
questions.question: How should pressure-treated bottom plates be handled at door openings?

options.B: Omit plate at door opening and add later
options.C: Install pressure-treated plate only at doorway
options.D: Regular lumber can be substituted at openings

explanations.A: Continuous plate would block the doorway and create a tripping hazard
explanations.B: Bottom plates at door openings are typically omitted during wall assembly and cut out after the wall is raised, or not installed in that section
explanations.C: Treated lumber should be used throughout when required, not just at openings
explanations.D: If treated plates are required, substitution compromises moisture resistance

questions.question: What is the advantage of factory-built windows and doors in engineered panels?

options.A: No advantages; site installation is preferred
options.B: Better quality control and weather-tight installation
options.D: Easier to modify opening sizes on site

explanations.A: Factory installation offers significant advantages
explanations.B: Windows and doors installed in panels at the factory benefit from controlled conditions, better quality control, proper flashing installation, and testing for water-tightness
explanations.C: Quality and labor savings are the main benefits, not just material cost
explanations.D: Factory-installed units are actually more difficult to modify

questions.subtask: D-12.02 Constructs dimensional lumber wall framing
questions.question: What is the purpose of hold-down anchors in shear wall construction?

options.A: To prevent walls from sliding horizontally
options.B: To resist uplift forces at shear wall ends
options.C: To attach bottom plate to foundation only

explanations.A: Lateral sliding is resisted by anchor bolts and plates
explanations.B: Hold-down anchors resist the uplift (tension) forces that develop at the ends of shear walls when lateral loads try to overturn the wall
explanations.C: Standard anchor bolts handle this function; hold-downs address specific uplift
explanations.D: Top plate connections don't require hold-down anchors

questions.subtask: D-12.02 Constructs dimensional lumber wall framing
questions.question: When should engineered lumber products be used instead of dimensional lumber for headers?

options.A: Only when specified by architect or engineer
options.B: When spans exceed dimensional lumber capacity or when specified
options.C: Never; dimensional lumber is always adequate

explanations.A: While specifications are important, there are practical reasons too
explanations.B: Engineered headers (LVL, PSL, LSL) should be used when spans exceed what dimensional lumber can handle or when specified for consistency and reliability
explanations.C: Long spans or heavy loads often require engineered products
explanations.D: Engineered lumber is used in both residential and commercial work

questions.question: What is critical when connecting multi-story engineered panels vertically?

options.A: Panels can be stacked without special connections
options.B: Following specific inter-story connector requirements
options.D: Overlap is not necessary between stories

explanations.A: Vertical connections require specific engineered details
explanations.B: Multi-story panel connections require specific hardware and fastening details as designed to transfer vertical and lateral loads between levels
explanations.C: Adhesive alone cannot provide the required structural connection
explanations.D: Proper connection and load transfer between stories is essential

questions.subtask: D-12.02 Constructs dimensional lumber wall framing
questions.question: What is the maximum projection allowed for anchor bolts extending above the bottom plate?

options.B: 6 mm (1/4 in.) maximum

explanations.A: Some projection is needed for nut installation
explanations.B: This may be insufficient for proper nut and washer installation
explanations.C: Anchor bolts should project approximately 13 mm (1/2 in.) above the plate to allow for washer and nut installation without excessive protrusion
explanations.D: Excessive projection creates obstacles for floor installation

questions.subtask: D-12.02 Constructs dimensional lumber wall framing
questions.question: When is it acceptable to sister damaged studs rather than replace them?

options.B: Only for non-bearing walls with minor damage
options.C: Never acceptable; always replace damaged studs
options.D: Only with engineering approval for bearing walls

explanations.A: Bearing walls with significant damage require engineering evaluation
explanations.B: Even non-bearing walls may require replacement depending on damage extent
explanations.C: Properly engineered repairs can be acceptable in some cases
explanations.D: Sistering studs in bearing walls with significant damage should only be done with engineering approval to ensure adequate load capacity is maintained

questions.question: What is the typical tolerance for panel positioning during installation?

options.B: 13 mm (1/2 in.) from plan location

explanations.A: Panel positioning typically must be within approximately 6 mm of the design location to ensure proper fit, connection, and load transfer
explanations.B: This tolerance is too loose for precision panel systems
explanations.C: This much variation could cause connection and fit problems
explanations.D: Specific tolerances are essential for engineered systems

questions.subtask: D-12.02 Constructs dimensional lumber wall framing
questions.question: How should electrical boxes be secured in wall framing?

options.A: Nail directly to drywall from inside
options.B: Fasten to studs or blocking per manufacturer instructions
options.D: No fastening required; friction fit is adequate

explanations.A: Boxes must be secured to framing, not finish materials
explanations.B: Electrical boxes must be fastened to framing members using nails, screws, or approved mounting brackets per manufacturer specifications and electrical code
explanations.C: Adhesive alone doesn't provide adequate support
explanations.D: Positive fastening is required for safety and code compliance

questions.subtask: D-12.02 Constructs dimensional lumber wall framing
questions.question: What is the recommended approach for walls that will receive tile or other heavy finish materials?

options.B: Reduce stud spacing to 400 mm o.c. or provide backing
options.D: Heavy finishes don't affect framing requirements

explanations.A: Heavy finishes may require enhanced backing
explanations.B: Walls receiving tile or heavy finishes should have studs at 400 mm o.c. or additional blocking to provide adequate support and prevent deflection
explanations.C: Stud size alone doesn't address backing for heavy finishes
explanations.D: Heavy finishes require consideration in framing design

questions.question: What final inspection should occur before accepting engineered panel installation?

options.A: No inspection needed; trust the installers
options.B: Visual inspection only
options.C: Verify plumb, connections, and conformance to plans

explanations.A: Quality control verification is essential for engineered systems
explanations.B: Visual inspection is important but not sufficient alone
explanations.C: Final inspection should verify that panels are plumb, level, properly connected per specifications, and installed according to approved plans
explanations.D: Structural connections and alignment are more critical than appearance

questions.question: What is the minimum bearing length required for wood roof trusses on wood supports?

explanations.A: This bearing length is insufficient for proper truss support
explanations.B: This is the minimum for I-joists but inadequate for trusses
explanations.C: Roof trusses require a minimum bearing length of 75 mm (3 in.) on wood supports to ensure proper load distribution
explanations.D: While this provides excellent bearing, it exceeds the minimum requirement

questions.question: When calculating rafter length using the unit rise and run method, what is the first step?

options.B: Determine the pitch of the roof

explanations.A: Total rise is calculated after determining the run
explanations.B: Pitch is important but not the first calculation step
explanations.C: The first step is to determine the total run (usually half the building span), then use the unit rise to calculate total rise and line length
explanations.D: Line length cannot be calculated without knowing the run first

questions.question: What is the typical spacing for roof truss installation in residential construction?

options.D: Either B or C depending on design

explanations.A: This spacing is unnecessarily close and not economical
explanations.B: Common spacing but not the only standard option
explanations.C: Also a standard spacing for residential trusses
explanations.D: Trusses are typically spaced at either 400 mm or 600 mm o.c., with the choice based on design loads and roof covering requirements

questions.question: What is a bird's mouth cut on a rafter?

options.A: The cut at the ridge of the roof
options.B: A notch at the rafter tail for the fascia
options.C: A seat cut where the rafter sits on the wall plate
options.D: The plumb cut at the rafter peak

explanations.A: The ridge cut is a plumb cut, not a bird's mouth
explanations.B: The tail cut is separate from the bird's mouth
explanations.C: The bird's mouth is a notch combining a horizontal seat cut and vertical plumb cut that allows the rafter to sit securely on the wall top plate
explanations.D: The peak cut is called a plumb or ridge cut, not a bird's mouth

questions.question: When should permanent bracing be installed on roof trusses?

options.A: After all trusses are set and sheathing is complete
options.B: Progressively as trusses are installed
options.C: Only if specified by the engineer
options.D: Bracing is not required for trusses

explanations.A: Waiting until all trusses are set is dangerous and violates safety protocols
explanations.B: Temporary and permanent bracing must be installed progressively as trusses are set to prevent collapse during construction
explanations.C: Permanent bracing is always required per truss design and building codes
explanations.D: All trusses require proper bracing for stability and safety

questions.question: What is the maximum depth of a bird's mouth seat cut?

options.B: One-third of the rafter depth
options.D: No limit as long as bearing is adequate

explanations.A: This is more conservative than required
explanations.B: The seat cut of a bird's mouth should not exceed one-third of the rafter depth to maintain adequate strength at the bearing point
explanations.C: This would remove too much material and weaken the rafter
explanations.D: There are specific limits to prevent structural failure

questions.question: What type of bracing is required perpendicular to truss top chords?

options.A: Continuous lateral bracing at specified intervals
options.B: No bracing is needed perpendicular to chords

explanations.A: Top chord lateral bracing must be installed continuously perpendicular to trusses at intervals specified in the truss design (typically every 1.2-2.4 m)
explanations.B: Lateral bracing is essential to prevent buckling and ensure stability
explanations.C: End bracing alone is insufficient; continuous bracing is required
explanations.D: While diagonal bracing is important, lateral bracing is also required

questions.question: How is the unit rise of a roof expressed?

options.A: Rise in mm per 100 mm of run
options.B: Rise in mm per 300 mm of run
options.C: Rise in mm per 1000 mm (1 m) of run
options.D: Total rise divided by total run

explanations.A: This ratio is too small for practical use
explanations.B: 300 mm is not the standard unit measurement
explanations.C: Unit rise is the vertical rise in millimeters for every 1000 mm (1 meter) of horizontal run, or in inches per foot of run
explanations.D: This describes slope ratio, not unit rise

questions.question: What is the purpose of a truss erection plan?

options.A: To show only the truss spacing
options.B: To detail installation sequence, bracing, and special requirements

explanations.A: Spacing is included but the plan contains much more information
explanations.B: A truss erection plan provides critical information including installation sequence, bracing requirements, bearing locations, and special handling instructions
explanations.C: Material quantities are separate from the erection plan
explanations.D: Pitch is shown on truss drawings, not determined by the erection plan

questions.question: What is a common rafter?

options.A: A rafter that runs from plate to ridge at 90 to the ridge
options.B: A rafter that runs at 45 to the ridge
options.C: A short rafter between hip and ridge
options.D: A rafter that frames into a valley

explanations.A: A common rafter runs perpendicular (90) from the wall plate to the ridge board, representing the most basic rafter type
explanations.B: This describes a hip or valley rafter angle
explanations.C: This describes a hip jack rafter
explanations.D: This describes a valley jack rafter

questions.question: How should trusses be stored on site before installation?

options.B: Standing vertically
options.C: On blocking, level, and protected from weather

explanations.A: Ground contact can cause damage and moisture problems
explanations.B: Vertical storage can cause distortion
explanations.C: Trusses should be stored on level blocking to prevent warping, covered to protect from weather, and supported at multiple points
explanations.D: Leaning trusses can cause permanent deformation

questions.question: What is the purpose of a collar tie in conventional roof framing?

options.B: To resist outward thrust on exterior walls from rafters
options.C: To provide nailing for ceiling finish

explanations.A: The ridge board is supported by the rafters themselves
explanations.B: Collar ties connect opposing rafters in the upper third of the roof to resist the outward thrust that rafters exert on walls
explanations.C: Ceiling joists serve this purpose, not collar ties
explanations.D: Sheathing is supported directly by rafters

questions.question: What is a girder truss?

options.A: A standard truss with extra bracing
options.B: A heavily reinforced truss designed to carry other trusses
options.C: A truss used only at building ends
options.D: The first truss installed in a series

explanations.A: Extra bracing alone doesn't define a girder truss
explanations.B: A girder truss is specially designed and reinforced to carry the load of other trusses that frame into it, often at walls or building intersections
explanations.C: End trusses have different requirements than girder trusses
explanations.D: Installation sequence doesn't define truss type

questions.question: When cutting a rafter, which cut is made first?

options.B: The tail cut

explanations.A: The bird's mouth is typically cut after the ridge cut
explanations.B: The tail cut is usually the last cut made
explanations.C: The ridge cut (plumb cut at the top) is typically made first as it establishes the rafter's length reference point
explanations.D: Cuts must be made in a specific sequence for accuracy

questions.question: What should be done if a truss arrives on site damaged?

options.A: Install it anyway; it will be covered
options.B: Make field repairs with similar lumber
options.C: Do not install; reject and request replacement

explanations.A: Damaged trusses cannot safely carry designed loads
explanations.B: Field repairs compromise the engineered design and void warranties
explanations.C: Damaged trusses must be rejected and returned; only the truss manufacturer can authorize repairs using approved methods and materials
explanations.D: Field modifications are not acceptable without manufacturer approval

questions.question: What is the minimum size for a ridge board used with 2x6 rafters?

options.B: 38 mm x 140 mm (2x6)

explanations.A: A 2x4 ridge is too small for 2x6 rafters
explanations.B: The ridge should be deeper than the rafters
explanations.C: The ridge board should be at least one nominal size larger than the rafter depth, so 2x8 is minimum for 2x6 rafters
explanations.D: While acceptable, this exceeds the minimum requirement

questions.question: What is the maximum allowable bow in a truss before installation?

options.B: 6 mm per 3 m (1/4 in. per 10 ft.)
options.C: 13 mm per 3 m (1/2 in. per 10 ft.)

explanations.A: Some minimal bow is inevitable in wood products
explanations.B: This is conservative but not the official standard
explanations.C: This may be excessive depending on the truss design
explanations.D: Truss tolerances including bow limits are specified by the manufacturer and must be checked against those specifications before installation

questions.question: How should ceiling joists be positioned relative to rafters?

options.B: Parallel to rafters
options.C: Aligned with rafters on the same side of wall plate

explanations.A: Perpendicular orientation doesn't provide proper load transfer
explanations.B: Parallel placement doesn't resist rafter thrust effectively
explanations.C: Ceiling joists should run parallel to rafters and be nailed to rafters on the same side to resist outward thrust at the plate
explanations.D: Opposite placement doesn't create effective connection to resist thrust

questions.question: What is a hip truss system?

options.A: Standard trusses with hip rafters added
options.B: A system using step-down trusses to create a hip roof

explanations.A: This describes a hybrid approach, not a true hip truss system
explanations.B: A hip truss system uses progressively shorter trusses (step-down trusses) to create the hip roof profile without traditional hip rafters
explanations.C: Truss orientation doesn't define a hip system
explanations.D: Valley and hip systems are different configurations

questions.question: What is the purpose of the rafter tail (overhang)?

options.A: To provide attachment for gutters and protect walls from weather
options.B: To increase roof strength

explanations.A: Rafter tails create an overhang that provides weather protection for walls, attachment for soffit and fascia, and mounting for gutters
explanations.B: Overhangs don't increase roof structural strength
explanations.C: The ridge is supported by the rafter body, not the tail
explanations.D: Ventilation is provided by soffit vents, not the overhang itself

questions.question: How should hurricane ties be installed on roof trusses?

options.B: On each truss connecting it to the wall plate
options.D: Hurricane ties are not needed for trusses

explanations.A: Intermittent installation doesn't provide adequate uplift resistance
explanations.B: Hurricane ties (or similar approved connectors) should be installed on every truss to resist uplift forces from wind
explanations.C: End trusses alone don't protect the entire roof system
explanations.D: Uplift connectors are required in most jurisdictions

questions.question: What is a valley rafter?

options.A: A common rafter in a valley area
options.B: A rafter running from plate to ridge in an inside corner
options.C: A short rafter between valley and ridge

explanations.A: Common rafters run perpendicular to the ridge, not in valleys
explanations.B: A valley rafter runs diagonally from the plate to the ridge in an inside corner where two roof planes meet
explanations.C: This describes a valley jack rafter, not a valley rafter
explanations.D: This describes the function of some common rafters, not valley rafters

questions.question: What is critical about truss heel height?

options.B: It affects attic ventilation and insulation space

explanations.A: Heel height is independent of roof pitch
explanations.B: Heel height (the vertical distance at the bearing point) must accommodate required insulation depth and ventilation clearance at the eaves
explanations.C: Heel height is critical for energy code compliance
explanations.D: While affecting appearance, its primary importance is functional

questions.question: When layout is done for rafter spacing, where should the first measurement start?

options.B: From the ridge board
options.C: From the corner or reference point

explanations.A: Starting from center would complicate wall coordination
explanations.B: The ridge is located based on rafter layout, not vice versa
explanations.C: Rafter layout starts from a building corner or reference point, measuring on-center spacing to maintain consistency with wall and floor framing
explanations.D: Systematic layout from a reference point is essential for coordination

questions.question: What is web bracing in a truss system?

options.A: Horizontal bracing between truss top chords
options.B: Continuous bracing attached to truss web members
options.C: Bracing at truss bearing points only

explanations.A: This describes top chord lateral bracing, not web bracing
explanations.B: Web bracing consists of continuous members attached perpendicular to web members to prevent buckling and provide lateral stability
explanations.C: Bearing bracing is separate from web bracing requirements
explanations.D: This describes diagonal bracing, not web-specific bracing

questions.question: What is the recommended method for cutting multiple rafters to ensure uniformity?

options.A: Cut each rafter individually from measurements
options.B: Use a pattern rafter to mark subsequent rafters
options.D: Cut all rafters different lengths for adjustment

explanations.A: Individual measuring introduces cumulative errors
explanations.B: After cutting and verifying a pattern rafter, use it as a template to mark all remaining rafters ensuring uniformity and accuracy
explanations.C: Estimation leads to inconsistent results
explanations.D: Uniform cuts are essential for proper roof alignment

questions.question: When can truss web members be cut or modified?

options.B: Only with manufacturer's written approval
options.D: Web members can never be cut

explanations.A: Unauthorized cutting compromises structural integrity
explanations.B: Any modification to truss members requires written approval from the truss manufacturer or a qualified engineer, as trusses are engineered systems
explanations.C: Field reinforcement doesn't adequately replace engineered design
explanations.D: While rare, modifications may be approved in specific circumstances

questions.question: What is the purpose of purlins in roof framing?

options.B: To provide intermediate support for rafters and reduce span

explanations.A: Ridge boards are supported by rafters, not purlins
explanations.B: Purlins run perpendicular to rafters, providing intermediate support that reduces effective rafter span and allows use of smaller rafter sizes
explanations.C: Sheathing is attached directly to rafters, not purlins
explanations.D: Access provisions are separate from purlin function

questions.question: What is the correct procedure for lifting trusses to the roof?

options.A: Lift trusses one at a time as needed
options.B: Lift all trusses at once for efficiency
options.C: Lift in bundles, distribute across structure, then install
options.D: Slide trusses up a ladder or ramp

explanations.A: Single lifting is inefficient and increases crane time
explanations.B: All trusses at once creates dangerous concentrated loads
explanations.C: Lift trusses in manageable bundles, distribute them across the structure to balance loads, then install progressively with proper bracing
explanations.D: Manual sliding risks damage and is unsafe for large trusses

questions.question: How should rafters be fastened at the ridge board?

options.A: Toenailed from each side into ridge
options.B: Face-nailed through ridge into rafter ends

explanations.A: Rafters are typically toenailed into the ridge board from both sides, creating a secure connection that maintains alignment
explanations.B: Face-nailing through the ridge is difficult and not standard practice
explanations.C: While metal connectors can be used, toenailing is the standard method
explanations.D: Adhesive is not typically used for ridge connections

questions.question: What is the purpose of diagonal bracing on roof trusses?

options.B: To provide overall lateral stability to the truss system

explanations.A: Sheathing supports roofing, not diagonal bracing
explanations.B: Diagonal bracing ties trusses together and provides lateral stability to the entire roof system, preventing progressive collapse
explanations.C: Access provisions are independent of bracing
explanations.D: Ceiling finishes attach to bottom chords, not bracing

questions.question: What is a hip rafter?

options.A: A common rafter on a hip roof
options.B: A diagonal rafter from plate to ridge on an outside corner
options.C: A short rafter between hip and ridge
options.D: A rafter supporting hip jack rafters only

explanations.A: Common rafters run perpendicular to ridge, not diagonally
explanations.B: A hip rafter runs diagonally from the wall plate to the ridge on an outside corner, forming the hip of the roof
explanations.C: This describes a hip jack rafter, not a hip rafter
explanations.D: While hip rafters do support jacks, this doesn't define what a hip rafter is

questions.question: At what intervals should temporary bracing be installed during truss erection?

options.B: Every 5 trusses or as required by conditions

explanations.A: Ten trusses without bracing creates dangerous instability
explanations.B: Temporary bracing should be installed every 4-5 trusses or more frequently depending on wind conditions and truss size
explanations.C: End bracing alone is insufficient during erection
explanations.D: Bracing must be progressive to prevent collapse during installation

questions.question: What is the minimum slope typically required for roof rafters to ensure proper drainage?

explanations.A: This slope is too shallow for most roofing materials
explanations.B: While acceptable for some materials, this isn't the general minimum
explanations.C: A 3:12 slope (3 units rise per 12 units run) is generally considered the minimum for conventional roofing materials to ensure proper drainage
explanations.D: While providing excellent drainage, this exceeds the minimum requirement

questions.question: What should be verified before beginning truss installation?

options.B: Wall alignment, height, and bearing surface preparation

explanations.A: Simply having trusses on site doesn't ensure readiness for installation
explanations.B: Walls must be plumb, at correct height, properly braced, and bearing surfaces must be level before truss installation begins
explanations.C: While important, weather is just one of many pre-installation checks
explanations.D: Sheathing comes after truss installation and bracing

questions.question: How should rafter crowns be oriented during installation?

options.B: Crown up

explanations.A: Crown down would worsen deflection under load
explanations.B: Rafters should be installed with any crown facing upward so that dead and live loads tend to straighten rather than increase the bow
explanations.C: Consistent orientation is essential for roof plane uniformity
explanations.D: Crown orientation significantly affects roof performance and appearance

questions.question: What is a piggyback truss system?

options.A: Trusses installed on top of each other for height
options.B: A two-piece truss system with separate top and bottom sections

explanations.A: This describes stacked trusses, not a piggyback system
explanations.B: Piggyback trusses consist of two separate truss sections stacked vertically, used when shipping height restrictions prevent delivery of full-height trusses
explanations.C: This describes girder trusses, not piggyback systems
explanations.D: Doubling provides strength but doesn't define piggyback configuration

questions.question: What is the purpose of a strongback in ceiling framing?

options.B: To reduce ceiling joist deflection and maintain alignment

explanations.A: Ridge boards are supported by rafters, not ceiling strongbacks
explanations.B: Strongbacks are braces installed perpendicular to ceiling joists to reduce deflection, maintain alignment, and prevent sagging
explanations.C: Finishes attach directly to joists, not strongbacks
explanations.D: Access provisions are independent of strongback function

questions.question: What type of fasteners should be used for permanent truss bracing?

options.B: Nails or screws as specified in bracing plan

explanations.A: Fastener type and size must meet engineering requirements
explanations.B: Permanent bracing must use fasteners specified in the truss bracing plan, typically 8d or 10d nails or equivalent screws
explanations.C: Staples don't provide adequate strength for structural bracing
explanations.D: Wire ties are insufficient for permanent structural bracing

questions.question: What is the maximum allowable overhang for a rafter beyond the wall?

options.B: One-quarter of the rafter span
options.D: As determined by span tables and loads

explanations.A: Fixed dimensions don't account for varying rafter sizes and loads
explanations.B: This ratio doesn't apply to rafter overhangs
explanations.C: While common, this isn't a universal maximum
explanations.D: Overhang limits depend on rafter size, spacing, snow/wind loads, and are determined by engineering calculations or span tables
